revision.text:
[[File:Portrett stamceller foredrag øystein signering liggande.jpg|thumb]] {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}}{{Infobox person | name = Øystein Runde | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = December 14, 1979 | birth_place = Ulsteinvik | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Norwegian | other_names = | occupation = [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[comics writer]] and [[comics artist]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} [[File:Henrik Ibsen taking responsibility, by Øystein Runde.jpg|thumb]] '''Øystein Runde''' (born December 14, 1979 in [[Ulsteinvik]]) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[comics writer]] and [[comics artist]].<ref>[https://snl.no/%C3%98ystein_Runde] in [[Store norske leksikon]] {{no icon}}</ref>
==Early years== Debuted as a 19-year-old with winning a competition in Norway's biggest youth magazine, Spirit, with a 3-page comic in rhyme. Broke through as a 21-year-old as co-writer and artist on Margarin, a family saga that was compared to [[David Cronenberg]], [[David Lynch]] and [[Dave Cooper]].<ref>http://www.aftenposten.no/kultur/litteratur/article1292143.ece#.UnAnrOCeHN8</ref><ref>http://www.abebooks.com/Margarin-Schau-Kristopher-Runde-Oystein/2060414375/bd</ref><ref>http://www.dagbladet.no/kultur/2006/05/08/465586.html</ref> Margarin ran in the magazine [[Smult]] and marked the co-writing debut of [[Norway|Norwegian]] comedian and musician [[Kristopher Schau]], who later created the TV series [[DAG (Norwegian TV series)|Dag]] <ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1711386/</ref> When collected, Margarin was considered a cult comic and got generally favorable reviews, with the exception of Norway's then-leading comics critic Morten Harper, who called Smult "Norway's most important comics magazine", but also noted that the main course, Margarin, was "disgusting" and "what happens in it could hardly be called sex".<ref>http://www.harper.as/artikler/smult.htm</ref>
Runde abandoned the detailed drawings of Margarin to create a strip of stick figures. The stick figure strips got collected in 2008.<ref>http://www.serienett.no/article/745/</ref>
==Writing== Runde then turned completely to writing: Futen with Knut Solberg <ref>http://www.serienett.no/article/272/slaende-godt</ref><ref>http://oyvindholen.wordpress.com/2008/09/07/eventyrlig-actionhelt/</ref> and two graphic novels for artist [[Geir Moen]], De Fire Store (The Grand Four). The steampunk action comedy took advantage of the fact that four of Norway's 18th century writers, [[Henrik Ibsen]], [[Bjornstjerne Bjornson]], [[Alexander Kielland]] and [[Jonas Lie (writer)|Jonas Lie]] are collectively called "the grand four". Runde and Moen reimagined them as a reluctantly assembled team of special agents, forced to cooperate because of a zombie invasion in the [[Frogner Park]]. De Fire Store book 1 got all over favourable reviews,<ref>http://www.nrk.no/kultur/litteratur/_de-fire-store_-1.4101609</ref> while book 2 was considered well drawn and full of ideas.<ref>http://ungdomsboka.blogspot.no/2010/08/de-fire-store-bukk-fra-luften-bukk-fra.html</ref>
2009 saw the publication of Runde's biggest project after Margarin, the Saga of Olav Sleggja.<ref>[http://oyvindholen.wordpress.com/2009/09/29/margarin/ Review] in Norwegian {{no icon}}</ref> Sleggja was drawn in a more realistic style than any of his other works.
==Projects== For Sleggja, co-director [[Lars-Petter Iversen]] and Runde created a live-action trailer.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5QQbbI18SSI Live-action trailer] {{no icon}} for Saga of Olav Sleggja, directed by Runde and Lars-Petter Iversen.</ref> Sleggja was praised for its intense and touching story.<ref>http://morgenbladet.no/boker/2009/barbarens_triumf</ref><ref>http://www.serienett.no/article/952/menneskenes-raskap</ref>
In 2015, Øystein Runde and Ida Neverdahl published a travelogue comic, MOSCOW, in English.<ref>http://www.brokenfrontier.com/moscow-centrala-review-oystein-runde-ida-neverdahl-norwegian-comics-jippi-forlag-moskva/</ref>
Also the book FUTEN, about a mythological tax collector, was finally published after 8 years of work by artist Knut André Solberg. Futen was well received.<ref>http://www.empirix.no/brutal-livsglede-og-mytisk-action/</ref><ref>http://www.dn.no/d2/2015/09/10/2120/Underholdning/superkittelsen</ref>
Together with co-director and producer Torstein Jacobsen and co-director Johanna Raita, Runde released a horror comedy, Last Christmas.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zo9piZYUULM&feature=youtu.be</ref><ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4524960/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1</ref>
== Bibliography == * ''Rundetid'' – Monthly strip in the zine ''Spirit'' * ''Margarin'' – published in the comic ''Smult'', written by [[Kristopher Schau]] * 2004 – ''Bjartmann'' – [[Jippi Comics]], Oslo * 2004 – ''Bjartmann er din presang'' – [[Jippi Comics]] * 2006 – ''Margarin'' – collected edition in hardcover [[Seriehuset AS]] * 2007 – ''De Fire Store'' – graphic novel in hardcover, drawn by Geir moen [[Gyldendal]] * 2008 – ''Rundetid'' – collected edition in hardcover [[Gyldendal]] * 2009 – ''Soga om Olav Sleggja" [[Samlaget]] * 2010 – ''De Fire Store – Bukk fra luften, bukk fra bunnen, Obstfelder er forsvunnen'' – graphic novel, hardcover, drawn by Geir Moen [[Cappelen Damm]] * 2011 – ''De Fire Store – julen 1898'' (Christmas special) [[Cappelen Damm]] * 2012 - "Elefanten Tommy" [[Cappelen Damm]] * 2012 - "Bjartmann" - collected edition in hardcover [[Jippi Comics]] * 2013 - MOSKVA - with Ida Eva Neverdahl [[Jippi Comics]] * 2017 - Stamceller - kroppens superheltar [[Gyldendal]] – kids' fact book about stem cell research. * 2017 - Los Angeles - with Ida Eva Neverdahl [[Jippi comics]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
